Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, and relevant authority, as detailed below.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 209C.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under Massachusetts General Laws c. 209C and c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, as the parties are residents of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and this Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters related to the custody of the parties’ minor children.

c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under Massachusetts General Laws c. 209C and c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, as the parties are residents of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and this Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters related to the custody of the parties’ minor children.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 223, \u00a.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 223, § 1, as both parties reside within Middlesex County.

See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody arrangements must promote the best interests of the child.
See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets the Massachusetts removal statute to require that removal be in the child’s best interests and repeatedly states that the ‘best interests of the child’ are the paramount concern in custody and removal decisions. The court affirms the trial judge’s custody and relocation orders based on an analysis framed in terms of the children’s best interests, thereby supporting the proposition that Massachusetts custody arrangements must promote the child’s best interests.
See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

See *D.M. v. J.E.*, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 619.raw_text: See *D.M. v. J.E.*, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 619 (1974).
See *D.M. v. J.E.*, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 619.proposition: It is well-established that the stability and continuity of a child’s environment are significant factors in determining their best interests.
See *D.M. v. J.E.*, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 619.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the voluntariness and validity of guilty pleas, prosecutorial recommendations, and plea bargaining procedure. It does not discuss child custody, best interests of the child, or factors such as stability and continuity of a child’s environment. Therefore it provides no authority for the claimed proposition and appears to be a mismatched citation.

*Beal v. Beal*, 429 Mass. 157 (1999).proposition: While joint custody arrangements like this one presume a level of cooperation between parents, as required under *Beal v. Beal*, 429 Mass. 157 (1999), Defendant’s conduct demonstrates an inability to adhere to the current arrangements due to his new employment.
*Beal v. Beal*, 429 Mass. 157 (1999).support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a Massachusetts criminal appeal concerning a murder conviction and evidentiary issues; it does not address family law, custody, or any requirement of parental cooperation in joint custody arrangements. The proposition about joint custody and parental cooperation is therefore unrelated to this case’s subject matter and misattributes a family-law principle to a homicide decision. As such, this citation does not support the claimed proposition.
